ai-ud4.8:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud4.8:1.3_0: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-ud4.8:1.4_0: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-ud4.8:1.5_0: But the wanderers who followed other paths were not honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And they didn’t receive robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-ud4.8:2.1_0: Then those wanderers who followed other paths, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, approached the female wanderer Sundarī,
ai-ud4.8:2.1_1: and after approaching, they said this to the female wanderer Sundarī:
ai-ud4.8:2.2_0: “Sister, are you able to do something for the welfare of your kin?”
ai-ud4.8:2.5_0: I’d even give my life for the welfare of my kin.”
ai-ud4.8:3.1_0: “Well then, sister, frequently visit Jeta’s Grove.”
ai-ud4.8:3.2_0: “Yes, venerables,” she replied, and did as they asked.
ai-ud4.8:4.2_0: that Sundarī had been clearly seen by many people frequently visiting Jeta’s Grove,
ai-ud4.8:4.3_0: They then took his life and went to the king’s counselor right there.
ai-ud4.8:4.3_1: and after going, they said this to the Kosalan King Pasenadi:
ai-ud4.8:4.4_0: “Great king, we cannot find the female wanderer Sundarī.”
ai-ud4.8:4.5_0: We won’t give it to you.”
ai-ud4.8:4.6_0: “But where do you suspect she is?”
ai-ud4.8:5.1_0: So the wanderers searched Jeta’s Grove. They pulled her body up from the ditch where they had dumped it, and lifted it on a bier. Having entered Sāvatthī, they went from street to street, from square to square, complaining to people:
ai-ud4.8:6.1_0: “See, Masters, what the Sakyan ascetics have done,
ai-ud4.8:6.2_0: Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral and wicked. They are liars and fake celibates.
ai-ud4.8:6.3_0: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ai-ud4.8:6.4_0: They have no asceticism, they have no spirituality,
ai-ud4.8:6.5_0: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ai-ud4.8:6.6_0: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ai-ud4.8:6.8_0: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
ai-ud4.8:7.1_0: Now, at that time people in Sāvatthī, abused and insulted them with abused and insulted them.
ai-ud4.8:8.1_0: “Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral and wicked. They are liars and fake celibates.
ai-ud4.8:8.2_0: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ai-ud4.8:8.3_0: They have no asceticism, they have no spirituality,
ai-ud4.8:8.4_0: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ai-ud4.8:8.5_0: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ai-ud4.8:8.7_0: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
ai-ud4.8:9.1_0: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-ud4.8:9.2_0: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went to the Buddha,
ai-ud4.8:9.2_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud4.8:10.1_0: “At present, Sir, the people in Sāvatthī abused and insulted them with abused and insulted them.
ai-ud4.8:10.2_0: ‘Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral and wicked. They are liars and fake celibates.
ai-ud4.8:10.3_0: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ai-ud4.8:10.4_0: They have no asceticism, they have no spirituality,
ai-ud4.8:10.5_0: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ai-ud4.8:10.6_0: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ai-ud4.8:10.8_0: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!’”
ai-ud4.8:11.1_0: “That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.
ai-ud4.8:11.2_0: and with the passing of seven days it will disappear.
ai-ud4.8:11.3_0: So you may respond to those critics with this verse.”
ai-ud4.8:12.1_0: ‘He who speaks what is untrue goes to the nether regions,
ai-ud4.8:12.2_0: as does one who denies what they did.
ai-ud4.8:12.3_0: Both are equal in the hereafter,
ai-ud4.8:12.4_0: the same is the same as the other side of the other world.’”
ai-ud4.8:13.1_0: The mendicants memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, then used it to respond to those critics.
ai-ud4.8:14.1_0: “He who speaks what is untrue goes to the nether regions,
ai-ud4.8:14.2_0: as does one who denies what they did.
ai-ud4.8:14.3_0: Both are equal in the hereafter,
ai-ud4.8:14.4_0: Are the same when they have passed away, in the other world.’
ai-ud4.8:15.2_0: “These Sakyan ascetics didn’t do it, it was not done by them, they swear it.”
ai-ud4.8:15.3_0: That rumor didn’t last long. It was seven days, then it vanished.
ai-ud4.8:15.5_0: and with the passing of seven days it disappeared.
ai-ud4.8:16.1_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud4.8:16.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud4.8:17.2_0: How well said this was by the Buddha!
ai-ud4.8:17.3_0: ‘That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.’
ai-ud4.8:17.5_0: and with the passing of seven days it will disappear.’
ai-ud4.8:18.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud4.8:19.1_0: “People out of control stab with words,
ai-ud4.8:19.2_0: like a battle-hardened by an arrow.
ai-ud4.8:19.3_0: (But) having heard that rough speech broadcast around,
ai-ud4.8:19.4_0: a mendicant should endure with no anger in heart.”
